@pnowojski Hi, thank you very much for the review. I will address the new comments and update the PR ASAP. Probably, it's easier to be reviewed with two updates: submit an update first then try to rebase to the current master(as the current master is quite different from the previous one).

Furthermore, looking forward to the merge plan. Let me know if anything else I can do. 
Thank you again for the review. 

Best, Hequn
Thanks for the review @GJL. Merging this PR.

@flinkbot approve all

Thanks @dianfu. Merging...
@tillrohrmann @shuai-xu thanks a lot for the review and the very good comments. The last build failure seems unrelated. Merging the PR.

I find it highly unlikely that the timeout is the issue, or that increasing it can have any effect.

The default timeout is 5 _minutes_. The failure literally means that the `MiniClusterResource` did not start within 5 minutes. Other tests running right before this test did not experience this problem in any way, so I'd exclude temporary performance issues on travis.

One interesting thing is that in both reported cases (linked in the JIRA) we allocated 3 slots instead of 6. For an extremely rare performance hiccup to result both times in exactly half the number of requested slows does not sound like a coincidence.

As such, -1.
No problem @Myasuka  😃
@flinkbot approve all
Thanks for your contribution @TisonKun
Closing to investigate. I think it's a race in the scheduler, or a problem with slot sharing.
Thanks for your review @GJL
Thanks for your review and improvement @GJL

@flinkbot approve all

Thanks for the update @dianfu. I spotted some additional usages but I will fix them while merging. In general the changes look good to me. I will do the final polishing and merge this.

Btw, it's not surprising to always see 3 of 6. This has to do with the number of task managers (2) and the number of slots we have to schedule. I would expect this to either allocate 0, 3, or 6 slots. We mostly get 6, that's why the test only fails sometimes, we don't get 0, because that would indicate that we didn't get any slots, which can't happen in this race, I think.

I'm not convinced that removing these tests for specific classes gets us anything if we don't remove the corresponding class as well.

In this particular example, if we would first remove legacy yarn code and WebRuntimeMonitor, then we could remove the `AkkaJobManagerRetriever` and it's tests completely. I'm looking into both issues right now, so I'd delay this PR until then.

Thanks for the review @zentol. Merging this PR.

Both the source and the sink use slot sharing with one of the 4 window-operator slots. This is also the root of the problem: because of some race or quirk the slot sharing doesn't work as it is supposed to and then the physically available 4 slots are not enough.

When it says 3 in this log, it means "source and window op 1" in one slot, "window op 2" in another slot. And the two slots of the other TM can't be used for some reason. It's a bit confusing because this thing allocates 6 logical slots (tasks really) to 4 physical slots (actual slots).

I know ... 😅
I enhanced the error message to try and figure out what exactly is happening.
I won't merge. @zentol go ahead with the merge.

@eaglewatcherwb could you include before and after screenshots? Do we have a simple, reproducible way to create failed jobs?

@Myasuka Thanks a lot for this contribution. Before starting the review, I first have a few high level questions. When reading the corresponding JIRA issue, the issue was mainly about making the `OptionsFactory` configurable in the flink-configuration. In contrast to that, this PR does not make `OptionsFactory` configurable, but instead exposes some partibular RocksDB specific options, e.g. compaction style. While this approach might be more comfortable for users, it is also less flexible/powerful than the approach described in the JIRA. So what that in mind I wonder if we could not do the following: 
- make the `OptionsFactory` configurable in the configuration.
- provide a default implementation of `OptionsFactory` that is based on (or using) the functionality that you currently have in `RocksDBCustomizedOptions` und can also be extended by the user. That means, this default factory will react to the setting defined in this PR.

With this, i) the user can easily configure particular options (like compaction) as with your current PR, but ii) they can also completely override the `OptionsFactory` in the flink config, e.g. because they need another option that we do not cover, and iii) they can extend the easy & flexible by extending the default factory. The default factory without anything configured will just use predifined options and keep them untouched. What do you think?
@leesf we may want to retain a short message while increasing the detail or specificity. We can log stacktraces but for CLI errors we should be more succinct.
I added the test (that is essentially written by @igalshilman)

@eaglewatcherwb thanks for the contribution! The description sounds like this problem could already be solved by the changes in #7662, which makes the slotpool driven by the same thread as the execution graph and should therefore avoid this type of concurrency problem. If you agree, please close the PR or just ping me again if not.
I think we're better off with a process and schedule for updating dependencies during the release cycle.

@GJL I've addressed your comments, and then decided to rework the savepoint-trigger tests.
Additionally I fixed a bug in the RestClusterClientTest where we never actually caused a failure in the client since the wrong method was overridden.

`nc` on MacOS does not allow use of both `-l` and `-p`. Ubuntu seems fine either with or without `-p`. What variant of `nc` is Flink's Docker image using? Is this [BusyBox](https://busybox.net/downloads/BusyBox.html#nc)? Rather than change the listed command, we may want to include a note that some variants of `nc` require the additional flag.
@tzulitai changing the ping seemingly did not work, but now I saw it anyways :-) I have no objections against the refactoring, looks good to me. 👍
Is this valid if we have a non-numeric accumulator? Not sure if that is an issue.

Please see the [Pull Request Review Guide](https://flink.apache.org/reviewing-prs.html) for a full explanation of the review process.<details>
 The Bot is tracking the review progress through labels. Labels are applied according to the order of the review items. For consensus, approval by a Flink committer of PMC member is required <summary>Bot commands</summary>
  The @flinkbot bot supports the following commands:

 - `@flinkbot approve description` to approve one or more aspects (aspects: `description`, `consensus`, `architecture` and `quality`)
 - `@flinkbot approve all` to approve all aspects
 - `@flinkbot approve-until architecture` to approve everything until `architecture`
 - `@flinkbot attention @username1 [@username2 ..]` to require somebody's attention
 - `@flinkbot disapprove architecture` to remove an approval you gave earlier
</details>
